holdings.text: Prior admissions by parties are substantive evidence under Sections 17 and 21 of Evidence Act; no requirement under Section 145 to put them to the party.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel drew our attention to s. 145 of the Indian Evidence Act. There is a cardinal distinction between a party who is the author of a prior statement and a witness who is examined and is sought to be discredited by use of his prior statement. In the former case. an admission by a party is substantive evidence if it fulfill the requirements of s. 21 of the Evidence Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cardinal distinction between party admissions (substantive evidence proprio vigore) and prior statements to contradict witnesses; follows Bharat Singh v. Bhagirathi.

anchor.surface_text: Bharat Singh v. Bhagirathi 1 . This Court disposed of a similar argument with the following observations Admissions are substantive evidence by themselves, in view of ss. 17 and 21 of the Indian Evidence Act, though they are number companyclusive proof of the matters admitted. We are of opinion that the admissions duly proved are admissible evidence irrespective of whether the party making them appeared in the witness box or number and whether that party when appeared as witness was companyfronted with those statements in case it made a statement companytrary to those admissions. The purpose of

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between a party's admission as substantive evidence under ss. 17 and 21 of the Evidence Act (no need to confront the party) and a prior statement used to contradict a witness under s. 145 (must be put to the witness, not substantive evidence)
precedents.cited_holding: Admissions are substantive evidence by themselves, in view of ss. 17 and 21 of the Indian Evidence Act, though they are number companyclusive proof of the matters admitted. We are of opinion that the admissions duly proved are admissible evidence irrespective of whether the party making them appeared in the witness box or number and whether that party when appeared as witness was companyfronted with those statements in case it made a statement companytrary to those admissions.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must, therefore, fail and is hereby dismissed.
